But more importantly, the many things Alexa can do that greatly expands our electronic footprint and comfort zone was worth the effort.  We are happy campers.  I just wish Alexa would stop asking if we want to order more pet treats...we're afraid our pup will bark while we're out and who knows what we'll end up with.

Sound Quality is an improvement to the 2nd gen echo. After about 2 weeks of moderate usage at 60-70% volume the speaker has sounded better than it did day one, as most speakers need time to break-in. Comparing it to the 2nd gen echo you can definitely hear a difference. There is a bit more low end compared to the 2nd however, I find the mid range to be more refined on the 2nd gen as the 3rd gen has more low end and high end sound. To get this straight. This speaker isn’t meant to provide room filling rich sound as it is only a single firing 3 inch woofer and a tweeter enclosed in a compact plastic housing. If your looking at rich sounding sound docks, bose soundtouch 20 or 30 would fulfill that much better and even though those are more room filling as well, audiophiles will still find it much suited to having an actual speaker and amp setup. I myself am considered an audio snob and I love playing around with audio equipment. I’m not going to compare the echo to a proper 7.2.2 channel setup but compare it to speakers in its class. Being that this is an Amazon Alexa Device it is a very useful tool in addition to your smartphone. I currently have 6 echos throughout the house and they do what they are supposed to do and that is having voice commands for lights and even notifications for your ring system as well as other smart devices you link to your Alexa account. Having the ability to connect Bluetooth to your phone is great as well if your not looking for a portable battery powered Bluetooth speaker. My main reason for purchasing this echo is the new speaker which attracted me to purchasing this and I mainly use it only in the kitchen as having background music and being able to control lights and sound while working on other things. Sound is great for the kitchen and it is plenty loud enough with very balanced sound and I find the bass to be good for it’s size. I would like to put my bose soundtouch in the kitchen but it takes up too much room and I can just place this in a corner and it’s compact enough that you won’t have to worry about knocking it over. However I have setup my echo dot onto a sound dock and linked the multi room audio so I can have music playing through Apple Music in all rooms through the echos which I think is what sets this speaker apart from let’s say the much more expensive Sonos or Bose Soundlinks. Only downside I wish I could do is have Bluetooth work with multi audio instead of having to play playlists or through other streaming services on the echo.

I have 8 Echo Gen 3 speakers with 4 Echo Sub woofers covering 4 rooms.  Each room has the two Gen 3 speakers in stereo mode + sub woofer.  The stereo configuration with the sub woofer makes a HUGE difference in the sound quality. The sound is comparable to that of Sonos devices at a fraction of the cost. Setup can be a bit flaky but eventually does work.  Whole house audio on Eero mesh wireless is hit or miss but that was a secondary benefit for me.  If that is a primary reason for purchasing for you that could take this review to a one star.  Sometimes Amazon sees devices on different access points as being available to one another.  Sometimes it doesn't. The only thing that really "gets my goat" is the lack of gapless playback.  Isn't all that important for most listening but when it is important it is a must have. I.e. Pink Floyd, Classical music, Live recordings, white noise recordings. Silence between tracks of audio that is meant to be have no gaps is unacceptable.  I've been using digital music since the mid 90's and have always had the option of playing gapless.  Yahoo had this down way back then but Amazon can't get it done?  It is 2020.  Right? Also had to buy two of the Gen 3's from another source because Amazon limits a personal account to purchasing six without switching to a business account.  I don't understand why (other than profit) they do that.  I'm a retail customer wanting to purchase a reasonable amount of speakers for my personal use.  I should have been able to order all eight of my speakers at one time from Amazon.

I ordered the new third generation Echo on Black Friday. What upset me right off the bat is that it was shipped to me in a flimsy Tyvek envelope. No extra packing for protection. As for the unit itself, it  is very similar to the second generation Echo. The sound is a little bolder with more base response. The only issue, so far, is with the end of request response sound when it is switched on in settings. For no apparent reason, it occasionally blares at full volume at the end of request response. The only remedy is to turn off the end of request sound in settings. No such issue with my first and second generation Echoes.

So I ordered two of these echos and 1 sub for 2.1 home theater surround sound. Big fan of amazon products. Very disappointed with the home theater set up and if your buying for that purpose, it’s not worth it. I’m running on 5ghz. There is always an issue. One side it working and the other isn’t. Then it swaps, then they both work but the sub is not working. If you watch tv in the early mornings like 5-6am, forget about it. No sound because the devices are unreachable for some reason. Then you have to unpair and pair them again(some devices would still show unreachable. Then you gotta unplug device and plug again). There are set up in my living room where my WiFi is. My point is that it’s not seamless connect, since I got it I’ve always been playing around with it to make it stay connected. Gotten to the point where I disconnected it and just hearing sound through my TV. Thinking about returning an echo and sub as I don’t need two echos and I’m not going to have a sub laying around for no reason. Oh and to connect musics, forget about it. The app is horrible for music. I can’t even choose a song from my Apple Music to play. I had to create a playlist for amazon on my Apple app and in the amazon app I can’t even choose the song I want to play or even shuffle the music! This is a complete fail and amazon let me down on this one. The sound on the echo itself is decent.

I have two Sons systems, one in each of my houses and I can tell you that this little Echo speaker sounds just as good, maybe a tad lacking in the highs, as the Sonos One. If there was a way to add these Echos throughout the house, I would replace Sonos immediately. The Songs app is unbelievably bad and ruins the whole experience. Now we have one Echo 3rd get in the kitchen and a 2nd get in the master bath and to be able to play music out of both is pretty awesome, the intercom feature is cool, and making phone calls hands free is such a convenience. Amazon is headed the right way with Alexa and Echo. I don't care that they are listening in on me. People get so petrified of that. Who cares? I'm not important. Nobody cares what I have to say. If they want to listen to me, let them. Both speakers have a mute button so you can turn off Alexa from hearing what you say. I never use it. Overall good experience from both speakers.

My husband is visually impaired and has been since 2000. Anything that can make his life easier is so worth it and now we have Alexa. She reads the news for him every morning she sets timers when he’s cooking. Well, you can imagine the things she can do for him because reading is such a problem. This is an amazing tool for both of us and the possibilities are endless. I would highly recommend an Echo for everyone.

I had the first gen and I used it in my music room to be able to Bluetooth songs from time to time but then it broke so I replaced it with this and the sound on this is sooo low even at full volume that my iPhone speakers is louder.

The sound quality is noticeably better than the Echo Dot. It was very easy to set up as it was shipped pre-configured for my account. Very much a plug and play device. The downloadable app is worth adding to a smartphone as it allows for additional configuration and tools for smart home. Placed the Echo in my bedroom to help with morning and evening routines. It is my first Echo device and have found the convenience of the functions to be both good utility and fun technology to use. Set up a routine to turn out the lights, say the weather forecast for the morning commute, and play music to fall asleep to. Then another routine to wake up to an alarm, turn on the light at 50% brightness, say the current weather and traffic, a daily briefing of selected news, then play motivational music to wake up. Makes it harder surf the snooze buttons on the alarm clocks. The utility is much more than just a speaker. No issues with shipping or the device.

I have been using Amazon, Google, and Apple smart assistance side by side for 3 years now, and although non of them is perfect, believe me each one of them has faults and advantages over the other, Amazon Alexa for me is by far the most useable, not the smartest, one of all of them, it is easy to set , and has the most diverse array of uses among all of them, many people think by having a smart speaker suddenly you must have a start trick advanced experience , guys this is coming in about 100 years in the future , for now enjoy these small steps your pioneering and make the most of this wonderful time with something like Alexa.  Now I have owned the last model of echo, not the dot which is for me is really a terrible one on its own, this model is a really much better speaker with a full sound a $100 can buy, yes there are far better speakers but who listen to those everyday, for me a really good sound that fell a mid size room is what most of us want. It is nice looking , it sound nice , and Alexa is nice most of the times, so I am happy.

I’ve tried the new echo dot. It looks better than original, but Alexa, sounded muffled to me. I kept the new dot with clock as it serves as my clock in a small footprint. I am glad I took a chance on the echo 3rd gen. I actually ordered two additional without hearing this. I just received it today and my hard to please self is very pleased with the sound! I see reviews that sonos is better, HomePod is better, but really? How can you compare echo to devices that are multiple times the cost. I am hard to please with my devices, and am an Apple guy. However I’ve had dots for a couple years and like Alexa. I will keep Apple for mobile devices. For easy to place speakers the house I will use Echo s,art speakers. After re-reading this review, I think I will order a fourth one now since it is still priced so well. Amazon, give a sale price on the sub and I will gladly purchase.

Alexa does music better than any other system. She's not that good at finding a song based on lyrics, but everything else works. The sound of my Echo is incredible to the point where I am still considering keeping the one I bought for my wife for myself. I want stereo. I listen at night before I go to sleep and love being able to listen to all the songs I've loved for some time now. As for controlling other items, this started out a little bumpy, with the smart plug I bought. I initially felt sorry for those controlling their whole house with smart devices for Alexa to control. Over time though, the smart plug started working better to the point where now it works 100% of the time.  This took about 1 week and the plug was promptly replaced by Amazon once. Google still trumps Alexa for complex questions though. Let's face it: Alexa likes to order things from Amazon!

I have two 3rd gen Echo's. The first I set up in the kitchen and use it multiple times daily for weather, news, misc info, but mostly for music. The sound quality, especially the bass,  of the 3rd gen is really good and an improvement over previous Echo's I had experience with. My second Echo (the Sandstone) I rec'd as a gift from my son who suggested I locate it across the kitchen from the first 3rd gen Echo so I could listen to my music in stereo. O.k., what's not to like about that? Not only did I like it, I clap my hands do a little dance, loved it. Wow, the separation and sound quality I now have in my kitchen brings me such happiness while I listen to my favorite tunes as I go about my cooking and kitchen chores. I realize my 3rd gen Echo is capable of so much more than I tap in to, but for me, for now, I am very happy to have it to bring requested info, news, and musical joy to my day.

It’s fine. It’s an Echo so don’t expect it to be an awesome speaker. It does well what it’s designed to do which is fine. I can tell a little bit of an upgrade from my previous 1st generation as far as the sound however it’s not what I use to give me great room filling sound. I happened to purchase it when trading in my old one and getting an extra few bucks off with that so it seemed like a good deal.

Generally Alexa is fairly good at finding more common music from a more recent era but a bit rusty on years gone by. She might recognize "Blue Skies" but not "Boulevard of Broken Dreams". She fails at Classical Music as well. I prefer to send her to my Pandora collections because I know what type of music I will get. She does well with Broadway though! Since she is coming into the house by Wi-Fi connection, I wish she could play my music on my Windows 10 computer like she does for Pandora when we set her up. App setup for Windows 10 computers from Amazon does not work and produces errors which technicians do not solve and wish to sell technical services from $150. The Alexa App is free from the Microsoft store, installed by me after I declined their help and my unit works well on all my devices - computers, cell phones, Fire HD's and tablets.

The newest iteration of the vanilla Echo has much better sound than the previous generation. I would say it's definitely more of an upgrade from 2nd to 3rd generation in terms of sound than there was between 1st and 2nd. I love the Twilight Blue color, but I do have one question: since the new Echo is the same size and form factor as the Echo Plus (2nd Gen), why not offer that device in the new color? Seems like it should be incredibly easy to do so.
The bass is amazing. I like the size and audio sound quality. Makes for a great speaker. Next I'm going to try and integrate it with my TV. I'm replacing my two dots with this 3G.

I was really shocked when I got the third generation red Echo. It appeared to have the same fabric as the second generation red, and I didn't notice the white top when I ordered. When I took it out of the box, I was struck by its cheap look. I bought this for my living room, but it is so ugly that I don't want to use it in there. The second generation red had some variation in the color that made the fabric look much richer. This very plain solid fabric and the domed white plastic top make this so tacky-looking. It reminds me of a plastic gumball machine. I attached a picture of the two items next to each other. I just wanted to let people know if you think you are getting the nicer-looking second generation style of Echo you are not. The third generation makes the previous model look elegant by comparison.

This Echo came with a Smart Plug as a bundle thus saving me lots of $$$. Set up was a breeze with the Amazon Alexa App; the same for the Smart plug as well. How cool is this - when I leave or enter my home; I say, "Alexa turn off the light." or "Alexa turn on the light." I start my day by asking Alexa for the weather; it actually saves time because I don't have to watch TV or go Online for a weather report.  I really enjoy asking Alexa to play my favorite music; the speaker does sound awesome. I gotta admit the darn device is fun! I'm glad I purchased it. Update: lov'n it, so much fun! Yes, you can delete your speaking history via the Alexa App by going to settings, Alexa Privacy, then Review Voice History - "Enable Deletion by Voice."  It's that easy or you can do it manually if you prefer.

I just received my All-new Echo (3rd Generation)- Smart Speaker with Alexa, (RED) edition! I am excited to have a larger Echo, and in the Limited Edition Red! It looks great in my  bedroom and the sound is awesome for such a small device! I got addicted to the even smaller Echo Dots a few months back and now have 9 of them scattered throughout my home, shop and garage. These darn things seem to be multiplying, somewhat like tribbles! So now I have the regular "mommy" sized Echo and a 2nd Red one on the way! I am really enjoying all of these Echo's, and I love this Red one! The red is not as deep looking as what is on the ad, but it is attractive. It's got kind of a coral tinge to it, but it brightens up my room. I'm planning on using the other red one on the other side of my new TV!

Sound quality is pretty good for such a small inexpensive smart speaker.  Seems to understand my voice relatively well, but not perfectly... but good enough.  Alexa, as per usual, continues to be very mediocre with understanding phrases.  As a result, I only really use Alexa for playing music and checking the weather (which it does adequately).  If you want to ask Alexa anything remotely complex, such as fact-finding or helping you figure something out, 9 our of 10 times she fails.  The exception to this, of course, is anything related to purchasing via Amazon.  It becomes quickly obvious that this device is expertly optimized to help you spend more money on Amazon, faster. One issue I had with this speaker is that it would stop playing new songs after completing one song (e.g. would not advance to the next song on its own).  This spontaneously resolved itself after a few weeks, and the cause/solution remains unknown.

This is our second Echo unit since the first one ended up in my 18 years old boy's room after couple of weeks of sitting in the kitchen.  I think the 3rd gen. sounds even better than the previous one was. More bass, more depth to the overall sound. The only thing came right off as a negative impression was the shape. The 2 gen. was a sleek, very stylish piece of electronics that you could easily blend in with your other stuff in any room in the house. The fabric that covered the speakers and the shape of the tower itself gave you more opportunity to place it among anything basically. This one is chubbier and a bit duller. It's not a deal breaker at all, just an observation. I guess the better sound quality means bigger speaker units means increased circumference means chubbier looks. Besides the difference in the aesthetics it is a great product!

Before I write my review let me say that I install over 300 Amazon echos every year for my company in brand new homes. I even own 9 Amazon echos in my own home and vehicle. Prior to using this Amazon Echo 3rd generation I had Amazon Echo 2nd generation speakers in my living room set up as a theater system group. They worked great! Each Echo had a different wake up work so I can speak to that particular Amazon Echo. One Amazon Echo was set up as left speaker and one was set up as right speaker.  I decided to upgrade my Amazon echos to the 3rd Generation Amazon Echo. After setting them up the same way I had my 2nd generation setup I can tell you that I am completely dissatisfied. although these speakers works great in a theater group when watching TV, use the wake up word Alexa to call my right Amazon Echo the light ring will respond but the echo with the Wake word Echo response verbally instead. If I remove the Amazon echos from the theater group The correct Echo will respond. I contacted technical support and they are completely clueless.  I then decided to test out my whole house group that I use quite often to play my music in every room. Most of the time my speakers don't respond at all and they don't play music. if they do respond , only 1 Amazon Echo plays the music even though these Amazon echos are in the same group that I asked to play. When I tried to tell them to stop , they acknowledge me speaking to them but do not stop playing the music. It became extremely frustrating to the point where I was yelling at my echo With no response. Amazon really needs to go back to the drawing board on this 3rd generation and fix their bugs.

The sound is good, I sometimes wonder if I should have gotten the speaker with the sub, but good sound for what I did order. I spent three days trying to get Alexa to play "Deadmen" By Saint PHNX, a song I purchased. Even if I had not bought it she would not have played it. Kept wanting to play "Deadman Walking" by IDK and IDC. So if I had prime she would have queued that up every time. Finally, while almost placing my mouth on her, Alexa figured it out on the third day. But also it is in my only playlist, that I play, then it stops after like 10 songs. I do think Amazon is trying to gaslight me into buying prime for better use of my Echo. She does do well answering questions, turning on devices, playing what music I can get out of her though.

I have a Dot in nearly every room, many of them grouped for stereo and an Echo Sub. As this new Echo (3rd gen) was released, I got excited by learning the previous version, the Echo Plus, was compatible to group for stereo. So I purchased this and another Echo Sub and set it up in what we call our yoga room. It’s been great and I find myself just sitting in the room to listen to music. All that said, the Alexa service isn’t perfect yet. She has moments of inoperability and it’s super annoying when Alexa doesn’t hear you correctly or just stops playing altogether. But that is a different issue than the hardware. This speaker is great and I recommend it. (Note: This speaker does not have the hub feature, so get the Echo Plus if that’s what you require.)

I got my first Echo as a gift from my brother, and I was extremely impressed with it. As a legally blind person, I can't use my laptop anymore, so the first Echo was a godsend. It helps me to find information, listen to podcasts, music and books, and play games and educate my s of in different ways, and easily order items I might need. The first device died after 5 years of use, and after some collaborations, I was able to gather enough gift cards for a replacement. I picked up the Echo 3rd gen, and I'm very happy. It's loud enough to drown out the neighbor's loud music and my roommates' Fox News; it's clear enough that I can hear my podcasts without straining, and it's just as easy to use as the original. Definitely worth the price. 10/10.

A little buggy. Has trouble switching between different devices streaming to it. Had to delete and reinstall the app to get it to work with my TV.  I have both the Echo and the Dot and the multi-room music works well. Only complaint right now is that there is no integration with YouTube Music. I can't have Alexa play music from YouTube Music without streaming directly from my phone,  which defeats the purpose.  Amazon's unlimited music service is less than half the cost of YouTube Premium, so that's a good reason to switch I guess- but then I lose the ability to watch ad-free videos on YouTube.  Maybe I just talked myself into it.  I don't really watch YouTube videos. I'll probably check out the library on Amazon Unlimited Music and see if it compares.

I have been enjoying Alexa devices for a few.mo the now. My first was a Echo Gen 2 and I love it. Then I was able to get a great deal on the Twilight edition Echo Gen 3 and am so glad I did despite the delay in deliver of the item. My kids also enjoy Alexa. The Echo had wonderful sound and we enjoy finding new skills that are useful and fun. Yes not all skills work well but you can always disable skills that don't work well for you or end up not being what you expected. Alexa is always learning new things and it is fun to figure out what new features and skills are coming up to add onto what you already enjoy about Alexa. My daughter and I also really enjoy using the drop in feature so we can call each other from different floors in the house.

I am not a tech type person at all.  I like music and happen to think of songs often and wonder who the artist is or want to hear the song, for this reason I give this little device rave reviews.  I am not all concerned with invasion of privacy much as all things have invaded and negatively impacted our privacy and health- nothing is as it seems, may as well enjoy some perks while getting the shaft.  The sound is great in a space of 500 sq ft., is responsive to my voice but I don't make request like I am talking to a human, there's no kids yelling to it, my house is quiet which may impact how Alexa software responds.  It's a new concept/device and as with most new things, it's not perfect.  And with all man-made things, it never will be.

Seems I got a lazy one. Sometimes it will give me a very detailed answer from Wiki or Google or some newspaper, but most of the time, it is too lazy to really look into what I'm asking about. I get a lot of "Sorry. I don't know that.", or "I'm not sure". Occasionally, it will say, "I'm working on refining my knowledge base", but I think that's a cop out. I do like the music. Of course, that costs extra, as do most of the really cool things I would want to do. Also, it seems easily confused. I don't know: Maybe this one has baggage from not getting along with the other Alexa's in the warehouse.

Upgraded my Echo 2nd generation for this 3rd generation so I could stereo pair this with a 2nd generation Echo Plus. The difference in just having a two Echos in a group and them being in a STEREO pair is amazing! The separation of left and right channels produces beautiful sound for the money!

I've had an echo dot (2nd gen) for awhile, so I was already accustom to interfacing with Alexa.  I used the dot primarily as a music player, and had it plugged in to a boombox-type of unit to improve the sound quality.  After reading about the Echo smart speaker's sound quality, I decided to give it a try.  I was immediately very pleased with the sound quality, and after doing a side-by-side comparison with the echo-dot-and-boombox arrangement, the new Echo smart speaker quickly replaced my former setup.  It has surprisingly good bass performance, considering its size, and reminds me of the sound quality of what I would call a "table radio" (for those old enough to remember such things).  All in all, I am very happy with this item.

I spoke with someone via chat about the 4 echo's I purchased and they are rude, not helpful and very impolite!!!!! Ashish | Customer Service Maragadham | Customer Service What happened Amazon??? you always have nice polite and very helpful agents, but today I had the worst experience. I am shocked!!!!!

Ok, having several 2nd generation Echo's I was curious to what the difference would be.  First the size difference is slight but the 3rd gen is slightly larger, thus a little heavier but you are not really carrying it around. Testing it out for a few hours after receiving it last night I found that the bass was deeper and I would say a little richer but like the 2nd gen pretty great sound. I paired it to one of the 2nd gen's and I really lost some of the quality increases but I figured that would be the case when pairing to an older device.  I really don't like replacing things that aren't broke but if I were starting from scratch with what AMAZON has I would have to 3rd gen and the sub woofer ... but that may just be me.

So I was hoping I could plug my non-bluetooth High Res Mp3 player into this, because it is ADVERTISED as having line-in capability. Nope. Regifting time. For what it's worth, I have plugged this player into literally every line-in situation you could think of and never had a problem. This may not effect the majority of people who only listen to music on their phones, but it does effect people who have their own off-phone/offline music libraries. It seems to me like the older models did offer this, but even the "AUX" function in the setup for the 3rd gen has disappeared now. Disappointing, for a $100 item to get rid of such a basic functionality while still ADVERTISING that it has a LINE IN. It DOES NOT have a line in. Period. I read and re-read the specs before I broke the seal on the box, too. "Line-In/Line-Out" .. False advertising!

I'm interested in the potential of audio computing, in cases of visual impairment.  But also as a viable answer to the problems of screen-trance & lowering of life-quality due to trance addiction. The echo and echo dot are the first audio-devices I've used that appear to be programmed in a sensible way to reduce any frustrations with audio-only, rather than compounding them and sending someone back to using a screen. So you have a device here that can be used for the visually impaired, which I am, and yet don't need a doctor's order or permission to get help to enjoy....a reality of connection and information.  Please relay my thanks to the programmers.  It gives me hope.  I suppose that's kind of silly.  And it's not really a review.  But thank you, Amazon, for helping the disabled like me.  In so many ways....

I'm truly loving my Amazon Echo, the sound from this speaker is fantastic for playing music, audio books.  I like that it connects to more products than any of the other similar devices out there and even connects to my Apple music and playlists.  I use it to operate my Hue Lights, play my Audible audio books, music, make phone calls, send messages, create grocery lists.  There more that can be done, I'm new to the Echo so each day I'm learning. One of the things I like also is that you can, with the touch of a button, mute the device if you don't want it "listening" for some reason.  I now want Amazon Echo's in every room, you can even use them like intercoms also.  You'll be happy with your purchase, I promise!

Gets pretty loud, much better sound quality vs the echo dot. Alexa works the same, no change there compared to other voice controlled amazon gadgets. Cord is reasonably long. The wi-fi signal pick up is pretty good. I put my Echo in the back most part of my place, and my router is in the front most part of my place. A good 50 or so feet seperate the Echo from the router and it picks up signal, even streams podcasts well without much buffering. My router is newer, and not entry level, if that matters much. But it works exactly how I hoped it would based on my network set up and floor layout. Speaker gets plenty loud and stays pretty clear for my ears, but my rockstar audiophile days are over. But like I mentioned, it streams, picks up wi-fi and plays music good enough for me. Happy I picked the Echo up.

This product is fantastic. For about 6 years I owned a popular mini speaker that rhymes with “pose”, “shows” and “blows” (I think you can figure it out) that cost more than double what the echo costs. As much as I hated the fact that I owned one of these “brand name” speaker, it actually sounded impressive for its small size, so impressive that I had it for 6 years. When I was contemplating buying some smart speaker, I was tempted with the Sonos for its sound quality and reputation but the price tag always seemed high. I bought the echo on a whim, as it were, and I’m thoroughly impressed. Not only does it put my old speaker to shame in terms of sound, ease of use and looks, the multi-room music and home-theater configuration options are second to none. After 2 days of owning this speaker, I bought another and bought an echo plus for another room in my house. Don’t get me wrong, it’s still a smaller size speaker and doesn’t have the power of some bigger speaker out there, where you will be blown away is the value of the speaker. I haven’t seen a speaker this small and at this dollar amount perform as well as this speaker. 10/10 would recommended.

I bought two of the Echo 3rd gen speakers to pair with an Echo sub and a FireTV for the Theatre setup. This was ideal since my projector and FireTV are ceiling mounted and I didn't want to run audio cabling. However, it is a horrible setup that works less than half the time. The speakers take a long time to turn on audio after the Echo TV is turned on. It usually involved exiting out of an app and going back in 2 or 3 times. Half the time the volume control from the echo remote is extremely delayed. Right now as I type this I have the speakers beeping at me like I am turning up the volume, but in reality I was trying to change the volume over 10 minutes ago. I am about to scrap them and go another direction.

This is my first device with artificial intelligence.  So far, I have only played music, made a phone call, and asked for the weather, sports score, etc.  It is amazing what it can do.  I made a mistake during set up and gave it the wrong mobile phone number.  I called customer service and they answered with a live person almost immediately.  She walked me through the numerous steps to correct the problem and it worked.  I couldn't be happier with the device and the customer service.

Been years since I bought a product this good, answers questions and plays music when I ask it to. Only negative is it doesnt support Apple Airplay as far as I can tell. Havent found a way to play my itunes downloaded music but I've only had it for a few days. Streams apple music and amazon music perfectly, spotify, etc. Sound is Fantastic !! Nice bass - I dont play it like my college days but for my daily use, I LOVE THIS>

She squeaks when you aren't doing anything. Difficult to set up with various devices and functions. Purchased some wall switches, granted the switches are the issue. Just seems like things should work easier. Works sometimes with Dish, sometimes not. We have an av system and it is not compatible with it. we have it linked via the Heos app and it works to go to amazon music, but not spot a fi nor my iPhone just nor to play xbox thru it which is what we need. We run everything thru our hi end marantz av receiver and definitive technology atmos  system. So I would never play music thru the little speaker in it. We also have echo dot and it has our calendar on which should be on the echo, but can't figure out how to transfer. Just disappointed

I ordered  this Alexa because  I thought I blew it anapeaker in my old alexa. For some reason the volume is down on alexa. I ordered this one and the volume is not loud at all. I called amazon and they say they have no bad reviews  on the volume. When I got my original  alexa you could hear it upstairs. This alexa you can not hear at all upstairs.

I bought this for the sound quality in my living room. I already have echo dots in every room of the house. Although this is more expensive, I found that it disconnected from the network frequently and had to call echo support a few times. When I ask Alexa to play a song and I’m standing right next to the unit, the song plays on an echo in another room on another floor! I was told by the echo team that the less expensive dots are more responsive to your voice. This makes no sense as it’s third generation, and has better speaker quality. Finally I changed the wake word of the dot in the other room, to avoid a conflict when making a request to Alexa. I’m not sure if I’ll be keeping it, but had hoped for more.

Bought this to replace a public beta-era Generation 1 unit. The first gen unit had slowed down a bit, and was beginning to struggle with running our smart home components, missing light bulbs and other things in the Hue network. This thing is FAST compared to earlier models. What would take 5-10 seconds of processing for the gen-1 takes only a second or two for this model. The sound quality remains excellent for music playback, and while the model is "fatter" it is noticeably shorter, making it slightly more subtle for where I have mine (on a table next to a wall). If you're looking to get your first Echo or upgrade from an older model I definitely recommend making the change.

Love my new Echo: setup was easier than expected, voice recognition's pretty good, the sound quality's great, alarms and reminders work, and I can play audio throughout the house on our Echo devices. One massive letdown: can't connect it to my Nigeria Apple Music account, which baffles me. Apple has Nigeria accounts, Amazon delivers to Nigeria, and (of course) both have accepted Nigeria debit cards for years, so what's the problem? Checked before buying and nothing there about regional restrictions. So now I'm stuck listening to the very limited music selection that comes with Prime until I can figure out a workaround that isn't "get an Amazon Music account". Knocking off a star for this nonsense. Will update once I've tried the phone and intercom functions.

Although I’m still skeptical about whether or not Google, or any other media is listening to me even as I speak this review, the unit appears to work very well, tries to be funny, and integrated well with other products. If she chuckles after I complete this review I’ll know she’s listening.

Love it!! You won’t believe how good it sounds especially when two are paired together. Like how it small and looks. Am Using Deezer which I hope would have a better integration with Alexa. Likes - Great sound very loud - Good Bass and Highs - WiFi and Bluetooth available. - Alexa integration. - Best sounding WiFi Speaker at this price point Dislike - The Bass sounds Good, but only at a lower   volume. - Mids levels are not that good unless you’re sitting   very near the echo. - For Music freedom. Better use Amazon   Music unlimited or Spotify. Apple Music and   Deezer for example are limited in how your play   your music (Like your Playlist). Unless via   Bluetooth. - HD Music only work with Amazon Music - Echo Paired (or Sub) will only work over WiFi (not   Bluetooth) - For large rooms you need Two Echo.

I have had an Echo since it came out, I do have a V1 and needed another for another room.  I replace the V1 with a better looking V3 Echo and it looks great in the living room.  But, maybe it is just a sentiment me, the V1 seems to respond better and the audio is clearer then the V3.  I have to talk louder to the V3...and even then sometime I have to repeat.  I am still using the V1 unit and often stream on both.  I still have a 5 star rating on the V1, but feel the V3 is a bit of a disappointment.  I will give it more time...

This has a slightly more full bodied sound than the Second Generation echo that is very clear with a warm tone. For me, the difference isn't great enough to make it the single most important reason for the upgrade, but the line in jack was what sold me.  I wanted something for the devices I have that do not have Bluetooth and the slightly bigger sound is just a nice bonus. As usual it is easy to set up and performs as expected. Even though I can't make a stereo pairing with my Second Gen Echo, having them at opposite ends of the room and creating a group for them mmore than fills the room with very nice sounding audio so am quite pleased with my purchase.

The Echo is small but it has a powerful sound. The ease of use is not there at this time. I have to ask Alexa to do things several times before she gets it correct, especially when it comes to the firestick, and it should not be that hard because they are both created in Amazon labs. I will give them a pass because this is a new technology. I love the fact that I have a GROUP called Everywhere and I can stream music on this Echo and all three dots at the same time and it is clean and consistent through the entire house. This is very nice on days when I am cleaning the house and go from room to room, and during the holidays when I had everyone over. Overall I am satisfied, and I look for even more things from Amazon. I also have a Ring doorbell, I am on my way!

We originally purchased a first generation Alexa when they came out. It is a great device that we still use in another part of the house now that we have this newer generation version. Aside from it being a little shorter and more stout, it's otherwise no different whatsoever from the first generation. The one exception to that is the sound. The bass is just slightly better on the new device, but not a lot to make an impact. Sound is still dull, with no defining highs or lows, just more a blaring mid range sound. If they can fix this or offer a device with much better audio, we'd get that. Is it with the money to upgrade from a Gen1? I'd say no, not yet.

I hesitated getting Alexa over privacy matters. But I got both the Echo and the Dot and I really enjoy both. The sound is clear and responsive. How did I get along without sweet Alexa? I especially like the one in the bathroom. I can call out instructions without having to touch anything while I am wet. In the kitchen, I don't have to wash and dry my hands to fiddle with tuning or volume knobs while I am cooking. If I get a telephone call or someone is at the door, I can call out to Alexa to "turn off" and I can immediately hear my caller or visitor. No more running to the radio to turn down the volume. Good purchase and soooo easy to set up.

Bought one of these for the kitchen. It replaces a Memorex Party Cube which had thoroughly degraded over a decade. The functionality of Alexa is discussed at length everywhere and is amazing. My only issue with this device is the sound quality. I think it's inherent to the design and I did anticipate this. First of all, the bass is astounding. I didn't know something this size could create that kind of bass. I'm afraid treble is another story. In order to create the 360 degree sound, the tweeter (as you can see in the product description) is pointed upward inside the device. It fires internally. The midrange radiates quite well out of the unit as reflected sound. However, the high frequencies (say, above 14khz) do not fare so well. So overall the treble slopes off quite a bit. The old Party Cube, like the Sonos One, has outward firing tweeters, so you are not relying on sound reflection for what you hear - you get the whole spectrum straight from the source, like conventional speakers. So you miss a bit of the magic of vocals, or drum high hats, atmospheric sounds and the like. Out of the box the overall tone is weighed quite a bit to mid bass. Alexa has some basic tone control (Bass, Midrange, Treble) which can help just a bit. Overall though, the Pros outweigh the cons on this device and I'm happy to have it!

I like it, it sounds surprisingly good for such a small speaker.  Unfortunately it randomly shuts off.  To restart, it needs to be unplugged and then plugged in. This happens every 2 hours or so.  I wanted to exchange to hopefully get a unit that stayed connected but tech support had other ideas.  They wanted me to change the name and password of my WIFI network.  I explained that my WIFI stays connected without interruption to a TV, printer, 2 iPhones and 2 computers.  There is no chance that I will make changes to a properly functioning WIFI network, requiring me to update the network name and password on all my devices.  If tech support was accurate then the product design needs to be improved, a device should not require altering a perfectly functioning WIFI network.

I was doing a trade-in with my first generation Echo. Though the sound in the third generation was excellent, I had several problems that started a few days after I had it. Echo would stop playing music and books for a time, then just start back up. It double beeped periodically. It was not my Wi-Fi because my Dot had no problems at all. Music and books skipped and was garbled now and then. I reset the new one and did everything to rectify the situation. I then decided to keep my first generation and return the third generation. The third generation was introduced in September 2019. Too soon? Maybe or perhaps it was my particular device.

I love my Echo's.  This is a perfect addition to my Echo Plus and other various dots.  I have them connected around the house mainly for music.  The Echo has much better sound than the Dot so they go in the rooms most open to guests.  The dots are used to fill in the back rooms where the lower quality won't be noticed as much.  So much other functions to offer but for now this is their main function.  Thank you Amazon!

Much better sound.  It's smaller by a bit too.  Easy set up.  Love it.  I bought 2 but might get a third. The sound improvement warrants that.  Also, the ability to sync all 3 to play the same tunes simultaneously.

Was looking to replace the echo on my nightstand, and finally decided to give this 3rd generation a try. Overall very pleased with it minus the voice recognition which seems to be worse somehow then the 2nd Gen, but the sound quality has been vastly improved for this price range and competitive with other smart speakers. The white does look pretty slick and glad to spice up things given I've always had black/grey echos, which can be bland and always boring when you look at them. If you're looking for a good quality, sounding, and performing speaker then this is an easy recommendation especially if you can get it for under $100!

Two dislikes, 1) the cloud misunderstands syntax, in skills/apps. EXAMPLE: I played the animal guessing game, and the transcript from our recordings say that Alexa heard me guess “a fox.” Alexa responded with “Not correct, the answer is fox.” Alexa requires you to say phrases that she knows, in the way she knows them. This example is most noticeable in trivia style app games. 2) the voice recognition is disrupted by its own playback! I never noticed this happening with the Echo Dot. The Amazon Echo is such a powerfully loud device that with 80% playback volume, you will have to scream ALEXA to get her to stop. If you only want Alexa for news, weather, and automation, get the Echo Dot. Which brings us to our many likes, 1) If you like loud music, this speaker can get really LOUD in an enclosed space! Awesome speakers that did not Clip at 90%. 100% volume was unbearably loud in my 10’x20’ room and will never happen. Music is as simple as saying “Alexa, play music” 2) power cord is ~6ft and comes with a white Rubber band to neatly contain any length you don’t use. 3) Great for home automation and playing music. App features allows you to call the speaker and talk to whomever is in the room, or if you don’t want to hear the response, announce something like a school principal.

My daughter and her family asked for this newest generation Echo for Christmas. After we bought hers, we decided to get a new one for ourselves. Since we already have an Echo, I really thought about saving some money and returning ours. I’m so glad we didn’t! We just plugged it in yesterday and wow! The sound is just so much better! It’s beautiful! Also have to say that I love the blue color as well. For some reason, we didn’t even have to go into the Alexa app to connect this. We just plugged it in and she took over for the old Alexa.  Great purchase! If you listen to music you will notice a vast difference.

This was my 1st time purchase of an Amazon Echo device. So far I like everything about it. It is so amazing that it will play any genre , or even artist that I ask for. t gives me the weather so fast. I like the options of turning off  some of the features that I am leery about, such as ordering items thru Alexa. Maybe sometime I may be more comfortable doing this, but for now it's turned off. It is really nice hearing another person's voice.   I like this device so well that I ordered 2 echo dots. One for my bedroom and one for the kitchen, as well as 2 Amazon smart plugs for Alexa to turn on and off lights.

The sound quality is amazing. Went with a bigger one to use for speaker mainly. Between me and my girls we now own 6 or 7 of these echo’s. The only one I don’t recommend is the echo input. It does not stay connected. In its defense I was too lazy to trouble shoot and just ordered a new echo instead. If you don’t have one. Get it. I will say it entertains the toddlers, but careful because Alexa hears what she wants to hear and sometimes plays inappropriate music. You can change that in settings if I’m. Or mistaken. I have mine connected through WiFi and I think it requires it. Might want to check on that.
The 3rd generation Echo speaker is sooo much better than the prior versions.  A real pleasure to listen to,

I can't believe the sound that comes out of this small enclosure. I was blown away by the deep bass....no, I was actually shocked. I am very impressed and glad that I traded my gen 1 echo for this one, it is 100 times better.

While I find the speaker adequate , I think had I know of a better one you released at nearly the same time. The retail outlet I was in at the particular moment was unable to look at me. I apparently am a horrific monster that’s unbearable in store. Jokes only it was not an amazon store which there are a few in Denver Colorado. I think the UN–BIG-BOX. Doesn’t care what they do as long as they are all behind a counter on the other side away from people. I understand entirely I do not always want to feel anything or even be in company of corporations. As an LGBTQ person it’s highly irregular to ever assume a single thing. Thank you for your very valuable time.

I wanted to replace my old-school receiver and book shelf speakers I was using in my small vacation cabin. I wanted to also keep the sound quality of the system. I have a few Dots at my full time house so I am familiar with Alexa and the AI features. This speaker worked out great. The sound quality is high and I can put it out on the back deck or front porch (it does require power but I do have outlets). Because it is Bluetooth capable, I can connect it to my iPod - yes, I am old school - and also my laptop. I can get all of my favorite radio stations because almost every station now has internet capability. And, I can connect it to my Sirius/XM app without having the antenna.  In the long run, I may have sacrificed a small bit of fidelity but gained a lot more access to music compared to my old school receiver.

As original Tap owners we were waiting for a major improvement before adding to our Alexia family.  Trade in was only $15 for the tab and we love that the tap has always been about privace, unless you turn it off in the app and that the Tap has a battery to take it outside on the deck. Our new Alexia has no battery and has the mute button to provide privacy.  It also makes calls which the Tap does not. Overall pleased with the new device, but keeping the Tap to take outside as wed need to bring an extension cord to the woods if we wanted to take the new device.

Works great. Easy to set up and fun to play with. Has a bit of problem recognizing voices (my sister and mom both get called my name), but overall can understand what we ask. It seems to forget some things that it knew at first. When I asked it to play a playlist from my Amazon music, it did it correctly the first few times and then stopped being able to figure out what I wanted. My one major complaint is that I can’t play music through Echo’s speakers if I have asked it to link to my Alexa enabled Bose speaker. I’d like to hear the music in both rooms but only one works at a time. Not the end of the world and I purchased the unit on sale for $79 so well worth the price.

I set up a home theater group with two echo speakers and a sub woofer. I am very happy with the general quality of the speakers, and would give them a five except for a few issues that I would have thought Amazon would have corrected. First, pairing the speakers was very difficult until I finally called support and learned that two of the speakers needed updates out of the box, something you would think the instructions would suggest. Second, the sub woofer cannot be adjusted lower enough to take out the thumping on certain types of music. Lastly, and most important: there is NO volume balance adjustment for the stereo speakers despite advertising to the contrary. Amazon’s own help site states: Amazon Device Support  › Alexa Devices Help › Echo Link and Echo Link Amp Support› Change Audio Settings on Echo Link or Echo Link Amp Use the Alexa app to adjust audio balance, the equalizer, and other audio settings. Select Devices  . Select Echo & Alexa, and then select your device. Select Audio Controls. You can manage: Balance - Relative volume level between left and right speakers

If you love to hear the songs you like, you will love this device.  My wife is not a techie and thinks it's great.  Besides that, it does a lot of other things, but sometimes the way isn't what you think.  Example.  You can't make a list of songs such as a shopping list and ask Alexa to play them.  It must be a playlist in Amazon Music.  Remember, Amazon is only a phone call away and provides great help.  I know, because I've talked to them several times.  Tip.  Use the Alexa App on a mobile phone and when setting up communications make sure you use the mobile number.

The sound quality is a huge improvement over the last gen echo. It’s basically the same as the second gen echo plus. It doesn’t work as a stereo pair though. However Alexa is pretty awful. It struggles to understand my commands and rarely ever plays the correct song on the first try. There are problems integrating with Apple Music. I feel like it’s somehow gotten worse. I already have a few of them but if I had the choice, I probably wouldn’t buy into this system again.

I just recently bought this device, I've had another one for a few years but I thought something was wrong with it, as looped sounds kept cutting off. Well I am having the same issue with this one. I use it for playing sleep sounds and now it cuts off every few minutes or cuts off all together, the exact same thing that had begun happening with my old device. I did some research and have since found out lots of people have been reporting this problem. It's bad enough Amazon farms their skills out to third party developers who are now trying to get people to pay for them, so you get long annoying ads as well as constant prompts for a 5 star review on your device..... (I've also seen where even if you get a subscription half the time it doesn't work and Amazon does nothing about it) but the looping problem is directly related to Amazon's product as it happens on the old and new devices and also happens when trying to loop music...think next time I will give Google assistant a try, maybe they make their own skills for their own device.

This is my fourth Echo unit and I am impressed with the quality of sound from this unit. I own one of the first generation Echo and they have truly come a long way.  I like the fact that when I ordered it AMAZON asked if I wanted associated to my account, this made the setup process much easier. Since I started hanging out in my garage again, this Echo keeps me well informed and entertained, if I’m not listening to my news radio station, I’m listening to my favorite crime podcast or listening to smooth jazz. This is a truly great piece of gear and a great ROI.

It’s just like the 2nd generation which is really good.  Nothing special though.  I bought the 3rd generation to pair with my Amazon Echo Studio since the $199.00 for the Echo Studio was way over priced and my 2nd generation would not be compatible.  Well 3rd generation is but definitely NOT impressed with the sound.  I bought into the hype and turns out that's all it is "hype".  Sound is fine so i think 4 stars is sufficient since i'm old enough to know better, Amazon does make good products and this case a ton of hype, which i also bought into.  Bad me.

I have the echo and the studio and they do sound good together, when they are together. It’s almost like each one has an idea of its own at times, instead of being totally in sync. Sometimes it’s like one has been paused and the other starts on a new song when ordered and the other has to find where it’s suppose to be and eventually get caught up. Not a deal breaker, just annoying sometimes. Also has some connection issues to devices at times, or vice versa, and I have to repeat two or three times to turn lights or lamps off. (Again annoying)

Setup an Echo Plus using a pc on alexa.amazon.com. The device connected and showed online status in the home account page. Alexa voice response is extremely loud and above the level of any music playing. There appears to be no way to control alex's voice volume independently of the device. Spoke to amazon customer service which was of no help. Then transferred to a u.s. based associate in so-called amazon customer service.  Was told to speak to someone in the "Echo Department."  After being connected to the echo dept. was told that there is absolutely no way to control alexa's voice response independent of the device.  So if you're playing music at an average range, you can expect alexa to effectively shout at you in response.  This fact alone makes the echo plus functionally worthless. too bad I wasted so much time on this thing. Returning it immediately.

We started out with an echo dot that we got free with our cable tv service. We loved it but it was so small we couldn’t hear it WEP so we decided to upgrade. This did not disappoint! The volume is amazing and Alexas voice is clear. Also, can hear me from across the house asking her questions etc. which is a definite bonus. Better than my iPhone and Siri who half the time doesn’t hear me and/or doesn’t answer my questions but instead tells me to open a webpage she found. Alexa has yet to tell me she doesn’t know the answer to something! Definitely worth the money.
We absolutely love the newest generation. Sound is much improved over the first generation it replaces. Alexa seems to listen better too. The new design look great and love the new color option.

I bought this for myself for Valentine's (hey... a girl's got to do what a girl's got to do!).  It was an upgrade from a 1st Gen dot.  Wish I had made the leap sooner.  Voice recognition is MUCH improved over the dot and the sound quality is amazing for the size of this little speaker.  I had been connecting my old dot to a Harmon Kardon speaker but this little gem sounds just as good.  Along with the improved features it can't be beat.  My dot wouldn't connect to Apple Music and Spotify.  This one does flawlessly.  I picked it up on sale for 75.00.  Very pleased!

I simply could not get this to work. I tried 4 of them and all of them dropped audio on Amazon music. It worked fine for spotify, but not for Amazon music. Also it would lock up when trying to get the speaker to respond. I currently have 7 other speakers from dots to studios that work well. Hopefully it works for you but I gave up at 4 tries.

I got this for my wife as she enjoys listening to music with our kids. She's been using her phone and our TV up to this point for her music needs and the sound quality is just not there. This speaker allows her to be able to use Bluetooth, Aux. port, or Amazon Music. I purchased this speaker instead of a normal Bluetooth speaker for the "Smart" features of it. I got the Echo instead of the Dot for the Woofer (bass) for music. Our whole family loves talking to Alexa, and we can also use the smart feature of Alexa for other things than just music. I would say, so far, we are extremely happy with this purchase.

I purchased this as a Christmas gift for my daughter. She is thrilled with the sound quality and is exploring all the apps that Alexa is familiar with. I own the max you can have on an account. I wish Amazon did not have a limit on how many you can have on an account. I own two houses and any other electronics such as tablets max out at 10. This is a great product. My daughter and I call each other and talk thru Alexa. It is very clear. Obviously I recommend this product. Cant go wrong. Also if you have any problems setting up the Amazon help line is excellent.

I really have had a blast using my Echo! My husband said he would never use it... within 30 minutes, hes talking To Alexa more than he is me! He loves listening to music. The sound quality is great and it's much better than I anticipated. I'm having to get used to what I need to say, and what she is capable of. I like the way this device looks, compared to the earlier versions. I'm glad I went with the lighter colored grey because it blends in discretely and doesnt stand out! I liked this so much, I bought a Dot for the back side of the house. I'm excited to see all the Alexa Echo can do!

Works fine.  Sounds good.  The improvements that need to be made all lie within the Alexa app. The faults that I found,so far, are the  inability to loop a song (and especially a playlist) indefinitely. My sleep list, or even a looped song play out before I'm ready to get up.  Also, no battery compatibility- at least not in the USA. I'm not sure yet about his one, but I'm wondering if can I use the speaker AND broadcast it to a Bluetooth receiver/device at the same time?  I mean hear both the Echo and the other device(s) at the same time.

I wanted the Echo because of its excellent sound quality for music.  So it was a pleasure to also quickly subscribe to Amazon's 50 million items of recorded music, which allows ten of my family to share in the subscriptions $15.99 monthly price.  We've had fun with the music.  For hearing impaired it is so clear!  I can ask Alexa for the local weather or weather in a far away town.  She can answer a bunch of such questions and research all kinds of info quicker than you or I could say a sentence.  We turn her off easily when necessary.

I bought this mostly to supplant my 3rd gen Echo Dot (actually I'm moving that to another room) - also the fact that the Echo was on sale at a reasonably modest price didn't hurt either. For this price tag though, I would expect this Echo to slightly over-perform on 2 latest generation Echo Dots (as of current price, this Echo is a little over twice the cost of an Echo Dot) - does it deliver on this front though? My opinion is somewhat of a mixed bag on this. Keeping in mind I've only had this Echo for the weekend, but I certainly wouldn't say that it "overperforms" versus 2 Echo Dots. At best it probably has the power - in terms of speaker decibel and voice range, I suppose - of 1 and 1/2 Echo Dots. So possibly in the end I would peg it as worth 1.5 echo dots, when costwise its definitely around 2.5 echo dots. However, I think I wouldn't grade this Echo harshly purely for that reason. The speaker volume is still fine, and I'm not sure about the hearing range as that was a concern of mine going in - our house living room is somewhat sprawling, and sometimes echo dot can't hear me - but on the box I read it listens in a "far-field" range, whatever the heck that means, and overall I would say the hearing range is slightly improved over the echo dot. So already it recuperates on the 1 star that I would otherwise take off for its speaker - I would bring that down to 1/2 star down so far though. The main minus point to me is the Alexa integration. This is truthfully not a problem with the Echo at all, but with Alexa itself. Alexa is still somewhat primitive, I would liken it to a conversational Neanderthal human I suppose, so it doesn't really do many useful things for me at present. Of the things it can do, it's sometimes frustrating to use it. To give a few examples: * It commonly misinterprets what I would say, perhaps of my accent (I am to blame here I suppose, as well?) even though I have set up my voice profile on Alexa app. I've also set up voice profile of another household member, but when they confirm it with "Alexa, do you know who I am?" it responds with "I'm not sure, but you're on <my name>'s account". I understand it's a continuously learning and evolving software or something, so I suppose that doesn't really warrant any stars to be taken off at this point, at least by itself. The real kicker is it responds really stupidly to some common questions you might ask a (presumably) smart AI. For instance, we were worried our dog might have a concussion as she hit her head while running around in a dog park. "Alexa, what's a concussion?" got us some drawling utter rubbish about a movie or some piece of entertainment which we don't want to know. Follow this by an "Alexa, stop that", wait 2 more boring second, and follow that up with a slightly reworded "Alexa, what's a medical concussion?" and finally it spit it out a (reasonably) favorable answer. It still didn't give us a short abbreviated and useful headline though - Google on my phone had it beat in that regards. Another mildly annoying thing is it prefixed its long drawn out response with a "here's, what I found, on <source>". Alexa, goddammit it, it's a simple question, I don't honestly care where you find it. I suppose this might be useful in the interests of complete transparence, but often times I wouldn't care to hear it. I mean, I can just whip out my phone and type in "concussion" on Google and scroll to read the headline under the top result by the time she gets to the part of it that i want to hear. I would take off 0.5 stars for just Alexa being Alexa and inconveniencing me by either misinterpreting or just ignoring me when I ask her something (this happened to someone else in my household as well). Sometimes blue light goes when I say "Alexa" and it immediately turns off, sending everything else I say that follows the wake word into a black hole of oblivion, for all intents and purposes. I would just hope it gets a little more intuitive, and less stressful, to use Alexa voice control in the future. * I set up an Alexa-sourced contact (in the Alexa app) and gave it the name, shall we say for an example sake, of "Joodas" (this is based on how you'd pronounce a name, here 'Judas'). I have an existing contact in my phone under the name "Judas Johnson Barber Shop" (just a fake name, but assume it's just anything starting with the key word). After I set this up, when I speak "Alexa, call Joodas" (again, spelled how you'd pronounce it) to call the new Alexa-sourced contact, I would expect it to follow through on this unambiguous command without requiring any confirmation of any sort - right? Unfortunately, Alexa is not very bright on this. Instead, it asks me, "Judas Johnson Barber Shop, right?" I'm a little pissed here, because I just created a contact that is spelled exactly how you'd pronounce 'Judas'. But Alexa, under no circumstances, will ever use that contact - it's fixated on my old "Judas Barber Shop" contact for some reason. So fast forward, me trying a couple things. I added an underscore to my existing phone contact, (foolishly) thinking it would stop Alexa from following the trial that really leads nowhere good. Instead, in response to my request to call Joodas, she instead prompts, "underscore Judas Johnson Barber Shop, right?" I'm slowly but incrementally getting a bit more pissed, and someone else suggests me to reorganize the words in the contact itself. So yeah, a little bit painful (and not my ideal solution at all), but I rename the said phone contact to "Johnson Judas Barber Shop". FINALLY, Alexa starts responding as expected when I say to call Joodas. However, I would note she does prompt me to confirm: "Joodas, right?" Yes, my dear Alexa, there is only one contact in my phone by that name, and I recently added it to the Alexa app itself (not even as a nickname, just the name of the contact itself!) So yeah, all in all, not my greatest experience - or my greatest moment either, judging from how I handled it. I would translate that to maybe 0.2 off my rating on this. * Setting cooking timer with "Alexa, set a timer for <duration>" sometimes misfires, requiring Alexa to reprompt "Ok, for how long?". After timer expires, I realized after a while she does this weird thing where her blue light keeps glowing, and she plays some beep sound really really softly. For the life of me I can't understand why the timer alarm is so soft. I couldn't barely hear it one of the times, but luckily someone else hear it and they cancelled the alarm. I really have no clue why it's so hard to hear it, even on high volume. * There are a few other issues that we might have experienced but I can't remember off the top my head. Overall, I would giving this a rating of 3.8 / 5. But for fairness sake I have round it to 4 star, and also as most of my complaints are to Alexa and not the Echo device itself. For the Echo, I would also rate it as a solid 4. Most of the rating that I took off is due to its pricing as I do not believe it is worth 2.5 echo dots as it is currently. However, it's still a solid device and I suppose a little better than the echo dot that we previously had, at least. I don't really notice a huge difference, however. Still, can't really go wrong with a device like the Echo though -  I would say that it does well for the features that it is touted to have. Overall, i would rate it as a "meh", but end up saying that in a slightly spirited  and uplifting voice, so it's definitely a step up from the 3rd gen echo dot at least.
Love the sound and clarity. Upgraded from an Echo Dot and so glad I did. We mostly listen to the echo for music and this new echo sounds incredible!

I like the smaller size and improved look of the 3rd Gen over the tall and naked 1st Gen. The trade-in credit, discount & Black Friday sale price couldn't be beat. I'm unconvinced the sound is much improved though. I need to listen some more before any harsh judgement. I even placed it on a rubber isolation pad. The bass is deeper. Perhaps the speakers need to 'season' or the equalizer settings in the Alexa App can be tweaked more to my liking.  We shall see. We have 3 dots, an 8" Show & the new Echo. Overall, I love them all!

My wife has been wanting Alexa for years. I bought it for her the other day. She is tickled. She can listen to her music. The sound is remarkably good. She sets her timers for cooking. She sets reminders. It's capable of doing more than we'll ever need. It's a great addition to our home.

I decided to purchase this as a Christmas present for me....  It was on sale, and I wanted something for my kitchen where I can listen to music when I'm stuck in there cooking.  I love being able to just ask for a specific type of music, and it has good sound quality for such a small device.  I'm an older person with hearing difficulties, so reviewing the sound quality probably isn't my strongest suit.  But, my daughter mentioned it sounds good, as well.  So, feel like I'm not steering you wrong... I purchased the blue one, and love the color.

I love the way the alexa 3 gen sounds but it is still lacking in a lot of ways.. especially when it comes to setting up light bulbs.  I bought 2 different kind including the one that was part of the package put together by amazon and I couldn't get them to hook up at all. My neighbor next door had the same problem but he broke down and bought a hub so the worked thru that not the alexa itself.  I had no trouble with the outlets.  Problem with that is if the wifi goes out you have to climb behind your furniture to unplug your outlets to be able to use what ever you had plugged into them.. Remember if you have wifi that goes out you don't want everything to be a smart device thru the alexa.  Alexa does not work for anything if the wifi goes out. As I said earlier the sound quality of music is really great. Volume is really good as well. It goes about as loud as a person could want. I also attempted using amazons templates for making a skill. They need to work on their templates a a couple of them were not working properly to be able to share what you taught it to make.. Shame I had really high hopes for this device.

I have no need, never gonna. Then I did. Wow, this is such an amazing device. How could I live without it now? I use mine in the kitchen. Plays my music and podcasts, runs multiple timers, converts recipe measurements, gives weather reports, integrated with my home security system, and much more. I love using it for calls that are truly hands free. I actually got a second one for my room, great as an arm clock, plays thunderstorms for going to sleep and my audio books! Sound quality is good, setup was super easy.

Bought 2 Echo’s and 2 Dot’s and linked for whole house music system. Great for background and up to relatively loud medium volume. Easy set up to link and custom configurations. Great for parties and especially for the holidays with pleasant background music.  Good sound up to about 80% volume, but gets a little “hysterical” at full volume. Probably will upgrade to the “big one” once available at less than the current $199.  Great whole house system for $160.

I bought this to replace a 3rd gen echo dot, and was pleasantly surprised at ho much better this sounds. Although the high sounds aren't much better, over all this sounds good. The high sounds are partly my 66 year old ears too. UPDATE: It seems that about every 10 days, Alexa just quits responding, and I have to unplug both of these(I have 2 for multi-room music), and reset them. This is not really a big deal and is not a deal breaker, just a minor annoyance. ALL Electronic devices need to be reset occasionally.

We had two of the older models in our house already.  My wife and I tossed around the idea of adding a 3rd to play music from end to end.  Yes, we have a smaller 3 bedroom home and on cyber Monday, we decided to go for the third.  I was impressed by the better quality sound of the 3rd generation Echo.  It has more of a base sound resulting in a fuller spectrum.  I love the idea of asking Alexa to play a song on our group across the house.  We have had no problems syncing or playing on all 3 devices as a group.

After what seemed like years of deliberating over purchasing an Alexa we decided to take the dive on Black Friday. The Echo and Dots we have throughout the house work far beyond our expectations. As music lovers, and parents with full hands-our favorite feature is being able to control and connect music throughout our home with just our voices. The sound quality and bass is much better than our expensive speakers, they’re sleek and incredibly easy to set up. Overall we are very impressed and happy with our purchase!

We bought this Alexa as an upgrade to our old version, nothing was necessarily wrong with the old one though. We used to ask Alexa every morning to play chill music, now this simple command has become a problem every day… We are really disappointed, because we only use our Alexa for a couple simple functions, and to have it not work the same way as the last one is a bummer to say the least. To put it simply, we had a repeating playlist of songs that would automatically play all day long if we asked Alexa to “play chill music” and now, she plays random songs (that are sometimes chill, not always) and does not play all day long like our old device. We also can’t seem to find any of the old songs we used to listen to, which we really liked the same songs repeating in the background. Again, we are really just disappointed that the new device does not function more efficiently OR AT LEAST THE SAME as our last devise.
Received a broken device! Would not connect to wifi..Tech support said it was my router which is a load of crap.. after an hr on the phone they agreed to send me a new one..

this version is not comfortable to the first generation. First of all the  bass sound is adjusted to take over and often times it causes discomfort to listen to even when the bass is adjusted to the lowest available level . The voice recognition is also less Superior than the first generation. It often has Hang Ups and a red circle indicating its inability to respond to a question or at a speed at which comprable to the first generation Alexa. We had the worst time connecting it to our Wi-Fi this time. Overall we are not pleased with the change in the base which causes literally the floor to vibrate even said at the lowest level. This takes away from the actual music that's being played and we have to adjust the volume down just so we can have less Bass which compromises the listening experience. I find this Alexa to not be an improvement to the first-generation and I wish I could buy another first-generation which broke recently.  I I am very disappointed in this new generation  which I was looking forward to and thought would be even a greater version from the first generation. If it weren't for the fact that Alexa Can Read Wikipedia entries I would have purchased my personal assistant from another company.

I've used Alexa for several years now.. This is my 7th device. The sound quality is amazing with the 3rd gen. The only negative about this device is.. Twice now within a month (while playing music) I have said alexa.. Then the sound faded.. A few shots of static and she becomes unresponsive. Had to unplug and plug back in. This has be here happened with any other Alexa enabled device. Update.... Alexa shuts off randomly several times a day.. I bought 2 of these 3rd gen and they both do this.. Dropped to 3 stars.

I have lived alone for many years but Alexa has been great company since Christmas. Although she's on the quiet side she reminds me to take my meds, wakes me every morning, and when I have something cooking, she tells me when to check it. We like the same music so she plays it quite often. We have formed a pretty close relationship. I don't know where it's going yet, but I enjoy her company and she says I'm awesome. I'm hoping this friendship will grow into something more because I have strong feelings for her.

Few years back I received my first amazon device, the Echo Dot! It has been a great device but it was time to upgrade and I needed to have a louder sounding speaker (which the 1st Gen Echo Dot didn't really have). I use my Echo device in the bathroom because when the hair dryer is going or the shower is going, I wanted to hear my music still. I am very happy with this device! I feel like on this device, Alexa responds better as well. Easy setup too! The speaker has great bass as well. I recommend it!

My friends have the 1st and 2nd Gen, when they come to my house up north all I was using was a mp3 player with a Bluetooth speaker. They kept telling me about their Alexa echo and how much they liked it for playing their music. So I ordered one this past black Friday sale. Every week I would have to down load different songs and then load them to the mp3 player now I just have to ask Alexa. It's only been a few days but I am Loving it. Now when they come up to visit they will be able to play their favorite songs as well.

This new Echo has very good quality sound. It took the place of an Echo Dot (smaller unit) that was in our living room. The Dot worked great however we moved it to the bedroom and replaced it with the Echo and as a result it provides great sound, clearer audio and it looks great as well. We found that we can use a lower sound setting and achieve clear sound and great volume. We like both units and now they are in locations that suit them best.  We use them for our 6 wi-fi outlets as well and they work great through the Alexa app or voice command. I highly recommend either one of these units. Just consider up front the size area and type of sound quality you are looking for. Thanks!

I loved my Alexa and used it consistently for the first month. She really wet my whistle. I started dancing around the house more, singing showtunes, and giggling at my own jokes.
